11.words: So Megan Lim. Megan is a recent graduate from MIT who is currently working as an educational consultant with the MIT Environmental Solutions Initiative. As an undergrad, she created frameworks for student engagement with campus climate action, especially campus decarbonization. She also advocated for accelerated climate action 2035 instead of 2050 for zero Eurocarbon, as well as problem solving technically with students and alumni on how it can be accomplished, for example, with thermal energy networks.

19.words: Okay, next person is Chris Rothe. Chris is the Education Program Director at the MIT Solutions Initiative where his main area of research focuses on better understanding and expanding climate justice and sustainability education at MIT and beyond. Chris is also interested in exploring environmental education and community engagement that centers inclusive and anti racist practices and support students who experience challenging emotions in relation to the climate crisis.
19.title: Day 1 Breakout 3 - Maya

20.words: Joe Higgins, if I'm pronouncing right, was appointed Vice President for Campus Services and stewardship on November 1, 2019. Higgins provided key leadership in MIT's alliance with Boston Medical center and Post Office Square to enable the construction on off site utility scale 16 megawatt solar installation through a power purchase agreement. Adding carbon free energy to the grid while offsetting 40% of MIT's electricity purchases. The largest aggregated renewable energy purchase of its kind at the time of formation. It demonstrates a partnership and economic model for organizations of varying sizes undertaking climate action efforts. Since Higgins arrived at MIT, the institute has lowered net compass carbon emissions by 15% as of 2022.

70.words: Okay, so George Thompson is 55, male, income of 55,000, he has a high school diploma, he's a building maintenance supervisor, he leans politically right and he has a medium sustainability interest. So George Thompson is a building maintenance supervisor for MIT's campus facilities. At 55 years old, he has worked at MIT for over 30 years, watching the campus evolve and change. Despite his dedication to his job, he often feels overlooked in sustainability discussions. While his primary responsibilities include ensuring campus buildings are safe and operational, he is also keenly aware of the waste and inefficiencies within these structures. George believes that practical hands on solutions often get sidelined by theoretical discussions. He values hard work, reliability and accountability, which stem from his working class background. While he doesn't follow politics closely, he leans right in his views and tends to be skeptical about high cost sustainability measures. He sees sustainability as important, but is mainly interested in cost effective, straightforward solutions. George often wonders how MIT's ambitious sustainability goals will translate into his daily responsibilities in hopes for more practical involvement with facilities staff in the sustainability initiatives.

14.words: Joe Higgins was appointed Vice President for Campus Services and stewardship on November 1, 2019. Higgins provided key leadership at MIT's alliance with Boston Medical center and Post Office Square to enable the construction of an off site utility scale 60 megawatt solar Solar installation through a power purchase agreement. Adding carbon free energy to the grid while offsetting 40% of MIT's electricity purchases. The largest aggregated renewal energy purchase of its kind at the time of formation. It demonstrates a partnership and economic model for organizations of varying sizes undertaking climate action efforts. Since Higgins arrived at MIT, the institute has lowered net campus carbon emissions by 15% as of 2022.

Steve is an environmental planner by training with over 20 years of experience in environmental policy development and program implementation. He holds a bachelor's degree in International Economic Development from Brown University and a master's degree in Environmental Policy and Planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

156.words: Dr. Michael Grant is a 55 year old environmental scientist who works with a consultancy firm that has advised several universities on sustainability initiatives. Although he resides in Boston, he has professional affiliations with MIT and sees the institution as a key player in advancing sustainable technology. Dr. Grant believes professional profoundly in the role of science and technology in solving climate change problems and advocates for aggressive carbon reduction strategies. He fundamentally values knowledge sharing and believes that MIT's policies can set a blueprint for other institutions. While he supports MIT's sustainability endeavors, he suggests they should focus more on innovative energy solutions and interdisciplinary research collaborations to meet their climate commitments.

158.words: While much of the discourse was compelling, I must express my disagreement with the notion that small incremental changes are sufficient for sustainable progress. From my scientific standpoint, incrementalism underestimates the severe urgency of climate challenges. We need bold, immediate actions grounded in substantial scientific evidence. The emphasis on moderation seemed to sideline more ambitious initiatives rooted in innovative technology and holistic strategies. My experience suggests that to truly stand at the forefront, MIT must take decisive, sweeping actions rather than settle for gradual improvement. It surprises me that some still advocate such measured steps.

It's vital to conflate insights from engineering, social sciences and even humanities. As an advisor on sustainability initiatives, I've witnessed the transformative power when diverse academic fields converge towards a common goal. Therefore, MIT should actively promote cross disciplinary research projects and foster partnerships beyond the academic sphere. Moreover, discussions on leveraging these partnerships to influence policy and technological advancement would have significantly enriched the conversation.

191.words: Tom Spencer is a 62 year old retired engineer from a non profit organization that promotes renewable energy. While he lives in the suburbs of Boston, he has a keen interest in the local transport system that many non Hawaiian residents use to access the MIT campus in the Boston area. He has a pragmatic view of sustainability. He sees it as beneficial, but is wary of policies that seem to push too fast without practical grounding. Tom had little patience with measures he perceives as superficial or disruptive to the community, stemming from his engineering background where feasibility is critical. Although he values energy efficiency, he is skeptical about MIT's just fit. Indications for ethereal carbon goals theory might only reflect well in projections rather than in pragmatic results for wider societal gains.

8.words: So our first panelist for tomorrow is Megan Lim. Megan is a recent MIT graduate who is currently working as an educational consultant with the MIT Environmental Solutions Initiative. As an undergrad, she created frameworks for student engagement with campus climate action, especially campus decarbonization. She also advocated for accelerated climate action 2035 instead of 2050 for zero carbon, as well as problem solving technically with students and alumni on how it can be accomplished, for example, with thermal energy networks. So Megan is our first panelist. Then we have Chris Raby. Chris is the Education Program Director at the MIT Solutions Initiative where his main area of research focuses on better understanding and expanding climate justice and sustainability education at MIT and beyond. Chris is also interested in exploring environmental education and community engagement that centers inclusive and anti racist practices and supports students who experience challenging emotions in relation to the climate crisis. Then we have Joe Higgins, who was appointed Vice President for Campus Services and stewardship on November 1, 2019. Higgins provided key leadership in MIT's alliance with Boson Medical center and Post Office Square to enable the construction of an off site utility scale 60 megawatt solar installation through a power purchase agreement. Adding carbon free energy to the grid while offsetting 40% of MIT's electricity purchases. The largest aggregated renewal energy purchase of its kind at the time of formation. It demonstrates a partnership and economic model for organizations of various varying size undertaking climate action efforts. Since Higgins arrived at MIT, the institute has lowered net campus carbon emissions by 15% as of 2022. And the last panelist is Steve Lanu with a focus on climate and energy work. Steve works to develop, promote and Coordinate programs to advance the Institute's commitment to sustainable practices while integrating campus focused research and learning opportunities with MIT's faculty, students and the broader community. Steve serves on several advisory and working committees serving the Institute, the cities of Cambridge and Boston, and his hometown of Winchester. He's an environmental planner by training with over 20 years experience in environmental policy development and program implementation. He holds a bachelor's degree in International Economic Development from Brown University and a master's degree in Environmental Policy and Planning from mit. So, lots of interesting people. I can leave it here in case one of you wants to consult it. So I suggest that we take like five minutes to start writing down some questions that are coming up for you. And they don't have to be perfect. We're going to workshop them so that we can come up with a list at the end of the session. You can work in Paris if you want. You can just brainstorm silently. Whatever. Whatever you feel most comfortable with. I can get you notebooks if you.

Then we have Joe Higgins, who was appointed Vice President for Campus Services and stewardship on November 1, 2019. Higgins provided key leadership in MIT's alliance with Boson Medical center and Post Office Square to enable the construction of an off site utility scale 60 megawatt solar installation through a power purchase agreement. Adding carbon free energy to the grid while offsetting 40% of MIT's electricity purchases. The largest aggregated renewal energy purchase of its kind at the time of formation. It demonstrates a partnership and economic model for organizations of various varying size undertaking climate action efforts. Since Higgins arrived at MIT, the institute has lowered net campus carbon emissions by 15% as of 2022. And the last panelist is Steve Lanu with a focus on climate and energy work. Steve works to develop, promote and Coordinate programs to advance the Institute's commitment to sustainable practices while integrating campus focused research and learning opportunities with MIT's faculty, students and the broader community. Steve serves on several advisory and working committees serving the Institute, the cities of Cambridge and Boston, and his hometown of Winchester. He's an environmental planner by training with over 20 years experience in environmental policy development and program implementation. He holds a bachelor's degree in International Economic Development from Brown University and a master's degree in Environmental Policy and Planning from mit.

205.words: Sure. Evelyn is a high school science teacher at a local Boston public school and has a deep interest in educational approaches to climate issues. Having grown up in a diverse neighborhood, Evelyn works hard to incorporate environmental education into her curriculum. Despite limited resources, she believes in empowering the next generation with the knowledge and tools needed to address climate change. Evelyn advocates for schools to develop partnerships with institutions like MIT to leverage their research and resources for public public schools education. She feels MIT's sustainability initiatives could be more inclusive by offering workshops and resources to local teachers and students, fostering a more comprehensive regional impact.

274.words: So. Evelyn is a committed educator working as a high school science teacher in the Boston public school. At 36, she has spent over a decade in education driven by the prospect of making environmental literacy accessible to underrepresented communities. Having grown up in Roxbury, she experienced firsthand the challenges urban schools face and became passionate about bridging the gap between scientific research and practical classroom application. She values equity in education and strives to empower students with the knowledge and tools to be climate conscious citizens. Evelyn sees MIT's commitment to sustainability as a beacon of hope, advocating for partnerships between higher Education, citizens, institutions and public schools to foster community wide impacts. She envisions MIT sharing research and resources with local schools, ultimately inspiring students to pursue STEM fields and sustainability careers. She believes more work is needed to make these initiatives inclusive, ensuring all communities benefit from MIT sustainability policies. So her missing perspective is the discussions seem to lack a focus on how these sustainability initiatives can be democratized beyond the walls of mit. While there was talk of immediate actions and ambitious goals, the role of community engagement and inclusion of various economic backgrounds wasn't fully explored. There is also a gap in addressing how to actively involve students and educators from public schools in these efforts. How can we ensure students from resource trapped schools are engaged with cutting edge sustainability practices? How do we empower educators with tools from institutions like MIT to nurture future leaders in environmental science with their communities? I like Tony better.

I used to get very sick every winter because that's when the pollution gets like worse each year. And I would like go to like the hospital every winter as a kid for like four years because I would get sick every winter because of pollution. And that's like, it's just like very personal to me. And after I moved to the U.S. i grew up in California, I think was ninth grade when like the wildfires were really bad. And personally the fires didn't reach where I lived.
